I said I'd give an update of GECCO and how our Late-Breaking Paper
presentation went, so here goes...

The first couple of days were all workshops and tutorials.  The best
of these included a workshop on modularity and reuse, in which Ken was
a speaker.  Some of the speakers were virtually incoherent, but
nevertheless the session sparked a lot of ideas and included some good
discussion.  I especially liked Ken's suggestion that the best
approach is to allow for overall designs or body plans which are able
to exploit modularity, rather than the approach of haphazardly
evolving individuals and then trying to find "useful" modules (if I'm
understanding what he said correctly).

Another highlight, for me at least, was the tutorial on Evolutionary
Robotics by Dario Floreano.  He covered nearly a decade of research in
the area, included lots of examples, with videos, and sparked a lot of
interesting ideas.  Unfortunately, he ran over time and didn't leave
room for questions (though I was able to corner him later at a
reception and discuss a few things).

My presentation was on Monday.  I made a wise choice in using overhead
slides instead of a Powerpoint.  I attended several presentations in
which time was eaten trying to change the resolution of the laptop
monitors to fit the projection.  Anyway, there were more people than
I'd expected (I pretty much thought only the presenters would be
there).  It was a tiny room, but it was nearly full.  A couple of
presenters didn't show up, but the moderator just left gaps instead of
forging ahead with the next in line.  When it was my turn, I gave a
general overview of what we meant by "simplification" and
"complexification", briefly explained how NEAT works, then ANJI.  I
talked about the domain and how we set up the experiments, and then I
showed our results.  The audience didn't exactly look riveted, but I
got four questions at the end, which at least shows that some people
were actually paying attention.  If I were to try to present next
year, I think I'd try for the regular paper deadline, and hopefully
shoot for some slightly meatier material.

The rest of the conference was mostly paper presentations, many of
which didn't really relate to what we're interested in on this list,
but still interesting.  I met several interesting people from other
schools, and from industries and non-profits.  I tagged along to a few
meals with Ken and Joseph, and we had some interesting discussions.

The only touristy thing we did in Seattle was check out the new
Science Fiction Museum and Hall of Fame, which was pretty cool.

All in all it was a good experience...not a bad way to spend my vacation.

Derek
